5.author: Sayakai
5.body:
> As a healer you think I don't wish I had entire team of Red Mages and Paladins?

As a healer, I have never ever wished for a team of Red Mages and Paladins. Those guys waste damage to heal.

> Of course it'd be super nice. Or if we optimize damage all tanks should be DRK and GUN.

The biggest difference - DRK/PLD - is about 3%, and I expect PLD buffs (PLD just got a major rework so it's no surprise its numbers aren't fully fleshed out yet).

> And only SAM and BLK for dps... but no despite there being 'better options' people are free to play whatever they want.

[The best players would actually want monks.](https://www.fflogs.com/zone/statistics/49#dataset=99) Also, every team wants to fill all roles. 2 Melee, 1 Ranged, 1 Caster is meta. Because it means higher stats. You also have to factor in healer DPS as a function of DPS healing - Summoner is viable for DPS despite BLM having nominally higher DPS because it takes more pressure off the healers, which indirectly raises DPS.

Right now, all this works with all jobs being very close to each other because the devs put **a lot** of work into balancing them. They're playing a math game against the playerbase, and the more variables there are, the harder the game gets for the devs. When the devs can't keep up with the math, the playerbase develops a meta and excludes existing choices.

Adding skilltrees adds  a fuckton of extra variables to consider.

5.author: Sayakai
5.body:
> You must have a LOT of confidence in your ability to revive people then.

I mostly have a lot of confidence in my ability to keep people alive. Outside of narrow specific prog scenarios (where verraise is useful), me and my cohealer can take care of the problem, or we're wiping to mechanics before then anyways.

> So basically anything but WAR?

The difference to WAR is *one percent.* That's how narrow the balancing is. And at that point you have to figure in the monster WAR healing, plus fight-specific invuln benefits (the short holmgang cooldown can be very useful).

> Knew about teams. But didn't you just say you didn't care if you had rezzers? And now it 'raises DPS'?

Not rezzers, DPS healing. Every Curing Waltz and Phoenix regen is free healing that I don't have to do (unlike Vercure/Clemency it's off the GCD so it costs no DPS), so I can continue to stand there and cast glare instead of potentially having to invest a GCD into keeping someone alive.

>  But every expansion is going to add 2-3 classes eventually we'll get there eventually.

Maybe. That doesn't mean we have to just give up and throw the whole work away for a feature that will be hard optimized by the playerbase in a hurry anyways.

5.author: Sayakai
5.body:
> So how much does Summoner actually heal now? Because its healing used to be crap

~10% of a healer in savage, ~20% of a healer in normal.

Rezzing could still be worth it - but when people die so much the healers can't keep up with their swift allotments anymore then you're probably not having a very productive prog environment anyways. The rules for casual content are something different altogether again...

>  I just meant no matter what its eventually going to get a lot of variables. If anything they'd probably be better off getting used to it now then waiting for there to be 30 classes.

I think that instead they'll eventually stop making classes, the way they realized that more races now add an unreasonable workload and stopped that too. We got a gender for EW and we likely won't get anything for 7.0.

The problem with trees is that they now apply to classes, which is to say, to *all* classes. So if you offer just a binary choice to each job, you have essentially doubled the amount of variables to balance.

20.author: WaveBomber_
20.body:
Well yeah “it’s just a game.” Every conversation on this subreddit could be boiled down to and dismissed as “it’s just a game.” But we are indeed talking about playing that game and what’s courteous or rude to do when playing it.

And subjecting other players in the game to the consequences of *your* IRL choice to muddle your mind is most assuredly in the “rude” category.

It’s fine to suck at the game, of course (when you’re actively trying to learn), and mistakes can be easily forgiven (even the best players fuck up now and then). But quite frankly, making the decision to put yourself in a state of mind that’s more likely to make mistakes you otherwise wouldn’t with a clear head and then knowingly stepping into group content in that altered state is a shamefully rude thing to do.

By all means, have fun / feel good / do what you want for yourself. Just don’t let it become a problem for other people. Be responsible.

20.author: WaveBomber_
20.body: It’s leisure among other people, if you decide to queue up for something cooperative by design. Don’t be an inconsiderate ass. Don’t put yourself in a situation where you could be a potential problem for others, whether or not it gets so bad that someone initiates a vote-kick. Just… think outside of your self in what are supposed to be team efforts. Make that edible a humble pie and excuse yourself from group content while you bake. Do not make yourself a problem for others if you can help it, and you *can* help it in this case.

20.author: 0bsessions324
20.body:
That last point nails it. I'd have stopped doing it by now if I'd literally ever encountered anyone in game who cared. Christ, I'd straight up just drop group and save people the wait time on waiting out the timer to kick me if someone ever expressed a concern.

I'd call it a victimless crime, but jesus, it's not even a crime, I have been taxed for this shit and dammit, I will heal inefficiently if I want to.

20.author: WaveBomber_
20.body: …Maybe you ought to go get high and chill for a bit. You sound like you need it, with that kind of overreaction to my grounded take. Just don’t let yourself become a problem for others while you’re at it, yeah? Yeah.

24.author: ChiefExecDisfunction
24.body:
>Slide casting, while probably unintended, is a commonly accepted mechanic of the game. We recognize that because our local clients and the game client aren’t in perfect sync, we can move during a cast, before the game reports back to the local client

This is incorrect. Slidecasting is a specifically coded .5s grace period before the end of the cast. Ping interacts with it, but it's not caused by ping. It'd be a really shit game is finessing \*ping\* of all things were intended design.

That said, we were never told about it and it was almost certainly not originally intended to be used as we do now. The devs adjusted. They should adjust all the way and fit the UI to the game's behaviour.

24.author: ChiefExecDisfunction
24.body:
>Do you feel the same about learning when animations vs actual hits happen in a game like dark souls or monster Hunter or a fighting game

If they don't match up in a sensible enough way, that's called a scuffed hitbox, a mismatched animation, or both. In fact, these regularly get adjusted via patches in the games you mention.

33.author: Scipht
33.body: Ah, that's where you'd be mistaken. 49% of people are below average, and never consider BLM past the 50 rotation they used for leveling, if they bothered to level it at all. Only people who actually take the time to know BLM will understand how complicated it is

33.author: fortebass
33.body:
>49% of people are below average

this is not how statistics work, it is a bell curve, not a singular point, the average isn't a singular percent in the center.

so no, not really mistaken, i just understand most people are average, there's outliers on both sides no doubt but the curve favors the center, for obvious reasons.

33.author: Scipht
33.body:
This is a fundamental misunderstanding of a bell curve. If you translate the bell curve into a percentage of what is in the center versus what is outside, you will find that it's about 50-51% inside the center, and 49-50% outside.

While I was being a little funny, the fact is that the center point of the bell curve will most likely NOT recognize the complexity of BLM, because they aren't the optimizers in the upper 25th percentile.

The average player levels all their jobs and sits on their favorite. It is predominantly not BLM that the average range lands on

33.author: fortebass
33.body:
one standard deviation away from center in both directions is about 68% of the population, 2 would be just about 95, so on and so forth, you can say literally anything is 50/50 but that isn't how you read a bell curve.

most people favor the center, with exception(both good or bad) being extreme outliers, the range of people who are average isn't a single percentage and everything else is split above or below that.

33.author: Scipht
33.body: I apologize for writing my comment incrementally. I am not arguing the relativity of a bell curve. I am arguing about where players who understand the complexity of BLM fall on it

33.author: fortebass
33.body: and im saying that the average player would understand it, your saying they wouldn't, so as i said originally: to each their own.

33.author: Scipht
33.body: Statistics aren't a "to each their own" situation. What is your data for determination? Mine is a cross reference of my own experience, Reddit posts/comments, YouTube/Twitch videos, and a general opinion from the players I personally know. There is an overwhelming majority of players who say "I just leveled it to max on MSQ roulette and didn't touch it." Can you provide conflicting data of a more solid foundation?

33.author: fortebass
33.body:
> Statistics aren't a "to each their own" situation.

correct, which is why we both agree about how the average isn't a singular point.

you assuming people wouldn't understand it on average, and me assuming people would, however, isn't statistics.

>Mine is a cross reference of my own experience, Reddit posts/comments, YouTube/Twitch videos, and a general opinion from the players I personally know

you literally just said "personal bias" here.

>Can you provide conflicting data of a more solid foundation?

the fact that the rotation is known and used in regular play and recorded down by hudreds if not thousands of people vis a vis fflogs, for starters, on top of the fact that there is all those community discords to help people learn the game filled with more then a handful of players that you interact with.

>There is an overwhelming majority of players who say

overwhelming majority? prove it then, if you want to make claims that i need to provide evidence, you do the same, i specifically want you to prove this remark, for starters.

or are you trying to sound smart and just being confrontational cause you tried to argue "muh statistics" and would rather assume the worst based upon your own small sample bias then realize the average player can be aware of the upper skill celing and understand its complexity, even if they have failed to reach it.

especially so, with how many people ask for advice on how to play their class.

33.author: Scipht
33.body:
Whoa there, friend. Flying off the handle here. Literally everything any of us discuss about this game is flavored with personal bias. There's no reason to get upset about its presence in the discussion.

Considering you quoted my points, I don't see how you don't realize my acknowledgement of the things that I don't have an easy (or sometimes even possible) way to prove the data I'm using. I specifically stated what I was using, and acknowledged its anecdotal nature by asking if you could provide more solid data.

On the opposite side, you yourself have made a lot of anecdotal assumptions, not the least of which being the size and contents of my personal analysis. Where I asked questions, you declared yourself correct. Where I have been trying to have a discussion, you have been trying to be right.

By definition, the average player would have an average understanding of the most integral game concepts. This generally does not include the concepts of skill floor/ceiling in most games, but especially in a game as casual-friendly as 14. Also taking into account the worldwide nature of the game, and its relatively recent popularity surge since Endwalker, I wouldn't discount the likelihood that a large number of players have never heard of the concepts at all.

This is where I'm leaving off here, as I don't feel like there was even much point to this post, judging by the one I'm replying to.

40.author: basketofseals
40.body:
If you're playing solo you're MUCH better off doing a set up with building your combo finisher, which adds not only extra damage, but a more reliable burst as well.

Gap close>Stun>rising phoenix>enlightenment>gap close>combo finisher>riddle of earth if you have it already active, but don't worry about it if you don't.

As for frontlines, I don't know, it's a lot more complicated. Only engage if you have someone you can gap close out of combat with. Just LB people who are out of position or if a couple people are attacking them. It's not a job I'd personally field for frontlines, but I'm not the FL expert either.

46.author: Redwolfx
46.body:
I didn't fail the mechanic, this is Clip of strat of me successfully doing #1 Missle Front PoV, returning to party stack for the Laser mechanic, as described in the post you replied to. After that your job is done as missle #1, you continue following ring until Panto Ends.

I was streaming, helping people learn P1 Strats. This is prob one of the best examples how to do movement properly as Missle Front #1 as simple as possible using 1st puddle drop under Omega, this puts you closer to ring for 2nd puddle position, and also creating space for party behind you as visibly shown in clip.

We wiped due to people still getting comfortable with Movement, considering this is PF, i'm there helping people get pulls so they get comfortable with it.

It's pretty common to fail any mechanic as pf group in PF during Week 1 of release, esp. an Ultimate one of the hardest Newest content in the game. Not everyone has had months to do this mechanic let alone a even a day, so odds of failing is higher at the moment. There was Fresh prog people who i let in this party to experience P1, fact is the person who was fresh was able to understand this strat and seen most of P1 with guidance within short time.

It was same thing when I was doing DSR week 1 in PF. It would be better to show clip now, than wait months for clear vod.

When people get more time and experience less likely to fail. I'm not in a static.

The purpose of the Dots representation of how many people on field, vague positions, don't have to be perfectly on those dots, never said you have to be on those dots, i didn't type that, but that is what you interpret it. So let me explain to avoid confusion, so no more assumptions; You can be closer/farther, like NE/SW in Example 1-2, All i Said is pre-position NE/SW, same way i said Post-Panto Pre-Positions, and I didn't include the ring in Example 1-2 you determine how close far you go, but aslong as you in those general directions, didn't tell you how close or far, I separated Flex Dot as example as it's own separate possibility as an Example, Flex had to be typed out, while i should include the Ring around Omega to be more accurate, I felt it was understood, the dots below B and D is where safespots are to stand, but you can move in. If you want to adjust it for me, feel free to do so.

The only example, i said you have to be at that spot is for Panto movement, which has to follow these rules and spots. I typed that out purposefully in it's own section of the picture, because if you go where ever you want to go, you will likely wipe the group.

One of the biggest reason i decided to put a Dot in front of Melees and Tanks, because they generally in melee range, while healers and range usually in back row, i thought it made more sense if you don't think that makes sense, then okay! That's another interpretation.  But, remember that >!the two of them were meant to work their magic in tandem.  In theory, Taynor wouldn't be able to resonate the same with his own shard, since we was trained to resonate with Nyel's.  If it "felt familiar," it should feel like Nyel's instead.!<  

Of course, Pandaemonium >!actually throws a wrench in that.  We know that as Themis, Elidibus was able to mimick other magics ably.  It's entirely possible he taught that trick to Unu, who just figured out the right way to compliment the spell.!<

50.author: Petrichordates
50.body: They're shown as immediately becoming best buds too, he's definitely Nyel. The Themis thing is a bit too out there to be a thread the plot is intending.

50.author: EndlessKng
50.body: Probably, but it's something I wanted to mention just to prevent it from being a "gotcha!" idea.  I suspect that's more an innate trait he has, or perhaps something endemic to the Office of Elidibus (being able to see all sides necessitates adapting to their viewpoints, and makes it easier to work magics with others).  But, if there is no connection, then it IS an interesting coincidence.

50.author: Petrichordates
50.body: I just thought the idea was that Elidibus was very skilled and hardworking overall, though I don't remember much focus on a preternatural ability to mimic any magic.

50.author: EndlessKng
50.body:
Maybe it isn't mimicry proper, but his ability to adapt to new magics is certainly way too fast to just be "skill."  We see this three times: in StB, >!he's able to fight exactly like Zenos, despite to our knowledge having never trained in his style.!<  In SoS, >!he's not only summoning heroes to execute techniques, but can mimic spells and effects and extend them - True Living Dead, for instance.!<  And, in Pan, >!Themis adapts to Eric's Interment Magic almost immediately, despite again potentially never seeing it before.!<  

It's an adaptability that goes beyond "skill," IMO.

54.author: Heroman3003
54.body: I never said it was The Burn that was created by primals, only that it is a prime example of what happens when land is drained of its aether. And, considering aether drain is what primals canonically do naturally, in addition to ever-growing hunger for more signifiant sources of it, its not a stretch to say that if one is allowed to run rampant for long enough, another Burn is entirely possible.

54.author: Petrichordates
54.body: How is it an example when that's just a lie to cover up the true cause? We have no examples of primal summoning creating anything like the burn, only propaganda that claims this.

54.author: Heroman3003
54.body: As I said, it is NOT an example of what Primal Summoning does - it is an example of what aether starved land looks like. As for the active Primals draining aether out of environment thats also a general fact - known fact mentioned in Eorzia long before the Burn ever was. The Burn was not created by primal summoning, but primal summoning COULD create something like The Burn. Just because empire lied about The Burn being caused by primals doesn't mean they lied about everything else. That's the point of propaganda - they took two true facts (Burn is example of a land starved of aether; Primals starve land of aether) and made up a lie by combining the two (The Burn was caused by Primal summoning) to make their draconian policies look more justified.

57.author: Eternal_Ohm
57.body:
Yes, but wattage alone doesn't tell the full story. RTX 3000 GPUs, and RTX 4000 for that matter have significant issues with transient power spikes causing issues with PSUs, particularly ones of lower quality but even some high quality PSUs can experience issues with this.

It could be a PSU related issue, it could not be, without another it would be difficult to tell. But I do at the very least think other options should be attempted before going straight to the PSU as it would entail OP purchasing something that **may** not even fix their issue without having tried much else to fix it.

59.author: Shadow0assassin0
59.body:
“Those people did try to maximize their chance”

For max chance, wait until the last day of submissions. Last hour if you happen to have a schedule that allows for it. 

Find a plot with no current bids nearest to the end of that time. Essentially: you can’t have people add to your bid if you are the last. 

First lottery I entered I won as the only bidder. Same story for a lot of people. On Mateus, btw, so not a new or empty world. 


Anyway: point is, maximizing chance is less to do with where you bid, and more to do with when. If you don’t want other bidders, wait as long as your schedule allows so you can find an available placard without leaving time for others to also bid on it. 

As a side note, my personal experience/exploration seems to show that the subdivisions get less bids than the regular (maybe ppl don’t know/understand that subdivisions exists and how to get to them?)

59.author: Shadow0assassin0
59.body:
It works :)

Got my second choice place in Empyreum right away. My first choice had, with 2 hours to go for bidding, at least 3 bids in each ward. My second choice had none in one ward, so that’s where I bid. 

The short and easy version is: if you don’t want ppl bidding after you, don’t leave enough time for an “after”. But really, it boils down to being patient and willing to settle for 2nd or 3rd choice

64.author: throwwaway666969
64.body:
click start type in DX DIAG.

Go to administrator then check out the error log time stamp to find the error code when the program got terminated.

Load our computer up in safemode and uninstall all video drivers then reboot and do a fresh install.

Do the same with AUDIO as I heard the game has audio problems for people.

The pic is a common one thats been in game since ARR and usually tied to an overclocked GFX card.

Perform a  RAM CHECK to make sure your ram doesnt have a bad spot and the game keeps hitting it and crashing.

**Copy the game and paste it to another drive and try manually launching the game from that new spot.**
